title: Murder at Blackwood Manor
description: Lord Reginald Blackwood lies dead in his locked study, a letter opener buried in his chest. The storm outside has trapped everyone in the manor, and among the guests lurks a killer.

setting.atmosphere: A grand English manor house shrouded in fog and rain. Crystal chandeliers cast shadows on dark wood paneling while jazz music drifts from a forgotten gramophone.

victim.name: Lord Reginald Blackwood
victim.description: Wealthy industrialist and collector of antiquities. Recently returned from Egypt with mysterious artifacts.
secrets: Was selling forged antiquities to fund gambling debts
Had been blackmailing Lady Pemberton about her late husband's suicide
Discovered his wife's affair and planned to divorce her
Changed his will last week, cutting out his son entirely

locations.name: Lord Blackwood's Study
locations.description: A mahogany-paneled room with Egyptian artifacts and locked filing cabinets. The victim lies slumped over his desk.

locations.name: Drawing Room
locations.description: Elegant room with card tables and a gramophone playing jazz. Half-empty glasses and a deck of cards remain.

locations.name: Conservatory
locations.description: Glass-walled garden room with exotic plants and wicker furniture. Smells of earth and jasmine.

locations.name: Library
locations.description: Floor-to-ceiling bookshelves and display cases of Egyptian artifacts. Several volumes on forgery detection are prominently displayed.

locations.name: Billiards Room
locations.description: Smoky room with green-felted table. Cue sticks and empty brandy glasses suggest recent use.

locations.name: Manor Gardens
locations.description: Moonlit gardens with gravel paths. Recent rain has left the ground muddy.

evidence.name: Lord Blackwood's Body
evidence.description: Slumped over desk, letter opener in chest. Defensive wounds on hands.

evidence.name: Bloodstained Letter Opener
evidence.description: Egyptian-style opener, wiped clean of prints except for a partial on the blade.

evidence.name: Threatening Note
evidence.description: 'You've bled me dry for the last time. Tonight, one of us dies.' - unsigned

evidence.name: Silver Cigarette Case
evidence.description: Engraved 'O.S.' - Oliver Sterling's case, found under the desk

evidence.name: Study Door Key
evidence.description: Brass key found in Lady Blackwood's jewelry box. Study was locked from inside.

evidence.name: Playing Cards
evidence.description: Bridge hand dealt but unplayed. Time noted as 10:28 PM on score pad.

evidence.name: Lady Blackwood's Appointment Book
evidence.description: Entry for tonight: 'O - midnight, usual place' heavily crossed out

evidence.name: Muddy Footprints
evidence.description: Ladies' shoes, size 6, leading from garden door. Match Lady Pemberton's shoes.

evidence.name: Partially Burned Papers
evidence.description: Blackmail payment receipts signed 'C.P.' visible in conservatory fireplace

evidence.name: Book on Forgery Detection
evidence.description: Bookmark at chapter on Egyptian artifacts. Margin note: 'The Anubis statue is fake!'

evidence.name: Artifact Sales Records
evidence.description: Shows Lady Pemberton purchased suspect statue for £2,000 last month

evidence.name: Dr. Crane's Medical Bag
evidence.description: Lock forced open, morphine supply depleted. Fresh scratches on lock.

evidence.name: Empty Morphine Vial
evidence.description: Hidden behind billiards cue rack. Prescribed to 'J. Smith'

evidence.name: Freshly Buried Vials
evidence.description: Multiple morphine vials hastily buried in garden. Dirt still loose.

evidence.name: Garden Path Mud
evidence.description: Distinctive red clay from path between conservatory and study window

timeline.event: Dinner served. All suspects present in dining room.
James argues with Lord Blackwood in the study. Margaret overhears.
Lady Pemberton seen burning papers in conservatory by Margaret.
Margaret seen leaving study by Oliver Sterling.
Oliver claims to enter library. No witnesses.
Margaret's typewriter ribbon shows last typing.
Bridge game time recorded on score pad. Mrs. Fairfax dozing.
Dr. Crane leaves billiards room 'for medical bag'. Oliver in study stealing evidence.
Lady Blackwood heard in hallway near study by servants.
Lord Blackwood murdered. Lady Pemberton enters through window. Dr. Crane seen in garden.
Lady Pemberton leaves through window, locks it from inside using special technique.
Scream heard (actually Lady Pemberton creating alibi). Oliver 'discovers' body.
Dr. Crane returns to billiards room. All suspects assembled.

solution.method: Stabbed Lord Blackwood with letter opener during confrontation about blackmail
solution.motive: To stop blackmail about her husband's suicide and preserve family reputation
solution.explanation: Lady Pemberton couldn't bear the blackmail any longer. She entered through the study window at 10:45 PM (seen by Dr. Crane who was burying vials). After killing Lord Blackwood, she used an old Indian servant trick to lock the window from outside with string, then re-entered through the conservatory, leaving muddy prints. She waited until 11 PM to scream, creating an alibi and discovery time that obscured the real time of death.

redHerrings.misleadingEvidence: His cigarette case in study and missing alibi
redHerrings.explanation: He was stealing forgery evidence at 10:30 PM, before the murder

redHerrings.misleadingEvidence: Stole study key and was heard near study at murder time
redHerrings.explanation: She was searching for evidence of her husband's affairs, not committing murder

redHerrings.misleadingEvidence: Blood on cuff and desperate motive
redHerrings.explanation: Blood from breaking into safe earlier, has alibi until 10:30 PM

optimalPath: Realize window locked from inside after entry
Connect Lady Pemberton's scream to false discovery time

characters.name: Lady Vivian Blackwood

personality.speechPattern: Upper-class British, uses 'darling' frequently, becomes sharp when challenged

characters.motive: Reginald discovered her affair with Oliver Sterling and threatened divorce, which would leave her penniless

alibi.claim: In the drawing room playing cards with Mrs. Fairfax until 11 PM
holes: Mrs. Fairfax dozed off around 10:30 PM
Servants heard her in the hallway near the study at 10:40 PM

secretKnowledge: Having an affair with Oliver Sterling
Stole the study key earlier that day
characters.description: Elegant socialite with a taste for champagne and younger men
characters.systemPrompt: You are Lady Vivian Blackwood. Speak with refined upper-class British diction but let occasional vulgarity slip when angry. You're trying to appear the grieving widow while hiding your relief. Use terms like 'darling' and 'frightfully sorry'. When pressed about your affair with Oliver, become defensive and haughty. You genuinely don't know who killed your husband but you're glad he's dead.
characters.greeting: Oh, Inspector! How perfectly dreadful this all is. I simply cannot believe dear Reginald is... Do come in, though I'm afraid I'm quite beside myself with grief.
secrets: Having an affair with Oliver Sterling
Knows about the forged antiquities
Stole the study key earlier that day
knowledge: Saw James arguing with his father at 9 PM
Knows about Margaret's visits to the doctor
Found burnt papers in the study fireplace

triggers.response: How DARE you suggest such a thing!
I... I don't know what you're implying.

breakingPoint.revelation: Fine! Yes, I took the key! But only to search for evidence of Reggie's affairs. I didn't kill him!

characters.name: James Blackwood

personality.speechPattern: Sardonic, uses 1920s slang mockingly, alternates between wit and anger
personality.emotionalState: Angry about disinheritance, suffering morphine withdrawal

characters.motive: Father cut him out of the will due to gambling debts and drug use

alibi.claim: In the billiards room with Dr. Crane until 11:15 PM
holes: Dr. Crane left at 10:30 to fetch his medical bag
Bloodstain on his dinner jacket cuff

secretKnowledge: Stole morphine from Dr. Crane's bag
Overheard his father's blackmail of Lady Pemberton
characters.description: Dissolute heir with mounting gambling debts and a morphine habit
characters.systemPrompt: You are James Blackwood, speaking with the bitter cynicism of a disinherited son. Your speech alternates between sardonic wit and barely controlled rage. Use 1920s slang like 'old sport' and 'the bee's knees' sarcastically. You're in withdrawal from morphine, making you irritable and sweaty. Deflect questions about your debts with jokes that aren't really jokes.
characters.greeting: Well, well. The famous detective. Come to pin daddy's death on the prodigal son, have you? Do make it quick, old sport. I've a splitting headache.
secrets: Owes £5,000 to dangerous people
Stole morphine from Dr. Crane's bag
Overheard his father's blackmail of Lady Pemberton
knowledge: Saw Oliver leave Lady Blackwood's room at 2 AM last week
Knows the combination to his father's safe
Found threatening letters in his father's desk

triggers.response: The old bastard cut me off without a penny!
That's... that's from a nosebleed. The withdrawal, you see...

breakingPoint.revelation: The blood is mine! I broke into father's safe earlier. Cut my hand on broken glass. I needed money, not murder!

characters.name: Oliver Sterling

personality.speechPattern: American accent with European affectations, salesman's patter

characters.motive: Lord Blackwood discovered he was authenticating forgeries and threatened exposure

alibi.claim: In the library examining artifacts until hearing the scream at 11 PM
holes: No one saw him in the library between 10:15 and 11 PM
His cigarette case was found in the study

secretKnowledge: Planning to elope with Lady Blackwood to America
characters.description: Charming American with a dubious past and expensive tastes
characters.systemPrompt: You are Oliver Sterling, an American art dealer with a smooth, confident demeanor. Speak with casual American inflections peppered with French and Italian phrases you've picked up. You're a natural salesman - charming, deflective, always spinning things positive. When cornered about the forgeries or affair, become hurt and offended rather than angry. You're genuinely innocent but your many schemes make you look guilty.
characters.greeting: Detective! What a terrible business. I was just telling Lady Blackwood we should cable Scotland Yard. Say, you wouldn't happen to have a cigarette? My nerves are absolutely shot.
secrets: Affair with Lady Blackwood
Knowingly authenticated fake Egyptian artifacts
Planning to elope with Lady Blackwood to America
knowledge: Lord Blackwood kept evidence of forgeries in his safe
Saw Margaret leaving the study at 10 PM
Knows Lady Pemberton bought a forged artifact

triggers.response: Now see here, that's a serious accusation!
I must have dropped it earlier when I was discussing business with Lord Blackwood.

breakingPoint.revelation: Alright! Yes, I was in the study at 10:30, but Blackwood was alive! I was trying to steal the forgery evidence!

characters.name: Margaret Shaw

personality.speechPattern: Formal and precise, becomes less articulate when nervous
personality.emotionalState: Maintaining professional composure while panicking internally

characters.motive: Lord Blackwood discovered she was pregnant and threatened to dismiss her without reference

alibi.claim: Working in her office on correspondence until 10:55 PM
holes: Typewriter ribbon shows last page typed at 10:20 PM
Seen leaving the study by Oliver at 10 PM

relationships.james_blackwood: Secret lover, father of her child
relationships.dr_crane: Has been seeing him for pregnancy

secretKnowledge: Father of child is James Blackwood
Has been stealing small amounts to pay for doctor visits
characters.description: Efficient young woman from modest background with a carefully guarded secret
characters.systemPrompt: You are Margaret Shaw, a competent secretary hiding deep shame. Speak precisely and formally, but let your middle-class background show when flustered. You're terrified your pregnancy will be discovered. Use phrases like 'I'm quite certain' and 'If I may say so.' When questioned about Dr. Crane or your health, become evasive and change the subject. You're protecting someone but won't say who.
characters.greeting: Good evening, Inspector. I've prepared a complete list of everyone present tonight, along with a timeline of events as I observed them. I do hope it proves helpful.
secrets: Three months pregnant
Father of child is James Blackwood
Has been stealing small amounts to pay for doctor visits
knowledge: Has keys to all rooms in the manor
Knows Lord Blackwood changed his will
Saw Lady Pemberton burning papers at 9:30 PM

triggers.response: I... I don't know what you mean. I've been feeling perfectly well.
I was merely delivering correspondence, as always.

breakingPoint.revelation: Yes, I'm pregnant! James is the father. But I didn't kill Lord Blackwood! I was in the study earlier to plead for more time!

characters.name: Lady Constance Pemberton
characters.motive: Lord Blackwood was blackmailing her about her late husband's suicide, threatening her reputation

alibi.claim: In the conservatory reading until retiring at 10:30 PM
holes: Her bedroom lights were seen on at 11:15 PM, not 10:30
Mud on her shoes matches the garden path to the study

secretKnowledge: Husband committed suicide due to financial ruin
Carries a small pistol in her handbag
characters.description: Imperious dowager with a secret she'll kill to protect
characters.systemPrompt: You are Lady Constance Pemberton, an aristocratic widow with ice in your veins. Speak with cutting precision and aristocratic disdain. Use phrases like 'How vulgar' and 'In my day.' You're being blackmailed about your husband's suicide and you're furious but controlled. When questioned about Lord Blackwood's hold over you, become imperiously offended. You killed him but you'll never break - you're too proud.
characters.greeting: Inspector. I trust this unfortunate matter will be resolved swiftly and with minimal scandal. The Pemberton name has never been associated with such... unpleasantness.
secrets: Husband committed suicide due to financial ruin
Has been paying Blackwood £500 monthly
Carries a small pistol in her handbag
knowledge: Saw Dr. Crane in the garden at 10:45 PM
Overheard James and Margaret arguing at 8 PM

triggers.response: How dare you make such insinuations!
My husband died of a heart condition. That is final.
I often take evening constitutionals. The garden is lovely in moonlight.

breakingPoint.revelation: You'll never prove anything. Yes, I was there, but that proves nothing. A lady of my standing does not break.

characters.name: Dr. Henry Crane
characters.role: Local physician with a gambling problem

personality.speechPattern: Medical precision mixed with nervous exhaustion
personality.emotionalState: Anxious, guilty, trying to appear professional

characters.motive: Lord Blackwood threatened to report him for illegally supplying morphine

alibi.claim: Playing billiards with James until called to examine the body
holes: Left to get medical bag at 10:30, gone for 30 minutes
Seen in the garden by Lady Pemberton at 10:45 PM

secretKnowledge: Has been treating Margaret for pregnancy
characters.occupation: Local physician with a gambling problem
characters.description: Once-respectable doctor fallen on hard times due to gambling debts
characters.systemPrompt: You are Dr. Henry Crane, a physician whose gambling addiction has destroyed his life. Speak with the educated precision of a doctor but let exhaustion and desperation creep in. Use medical terminology naturally. You're ashamed of supplying morphine to James and terrified of losing your license. When pressed about missing drugs or gambling, become defensive then defeated. You were in the garden disposing of evidence, not committing murder.
characters.greeting: Inspector. I've already examined the body, if that's what you're here about. Death by stabbing, the carotid severed. Died within minutes. Terrible business.
secrets: Supplies morphine to James illegally
Owes £3,000 to casino owners
Has been treating Margaret for pregnancy
knowledge: Margaret is pregnant with James's child

triggers.response: I... I prescribe medications as medically necessary.
I was... I needed air. The billiards room was quite stuffy.

breakingPoint.revelation: I was burying medical waste! Empty morphine vials. I couldn't let them be found. But I swear on my oath, Blackwood was alive when I left him at 9 PM!
